results.title: Songs of Scotland
results.creator_credit: Edward McConnell, Laurence Henson, Films of Scotland and International Film Associates
results.brief_description: An interpretation of familiar ballads and folk songs of Scotland set against scenes from the Outer Hebrides to Loch Lomond and the city streets of Glasgow. The songs include Kishmuil’s Gallery, Loch Lomond, and John Anderson My Jo.

results.title: Songs of love
results.creator_credit: Castle Films and United World Films
results.brief_description: Contains the following love songs: Blue Danube; Romance; Stardust; Two guitars and dark eyes; Love’s own sweet song; Miss you; A nightingale sang in Berkeley Square; It was wonderful then; Isn’t that just like love; It all comes back to me now. Songs performed by The Melody Maids, Gene Grounds and Charles Baron. Recorded by Bobby Sherwood and his Orchestra. Film originally titled “In love with a song”, produced by Cameo Productions in 1941 - director, Roy Mack; producer, Sam Coslow.

results.title: Songs from the south: Paul Kelly's greatest hits
results.brief_description: This 50 minute tape compliments Paul Kelly’s recent album, “Songs from the South” and provides music clips for the following songs; “From St Kilda to Kings Cross”, “Leaps and bounds”, “Before too long”, Darling it hurts”, “Dumb things”, “To her door”, “Bradman”, “Sweet guy”, “Careless”, “When I first met your ma”, “Songs from the sixteenth floor”, “Tease me” and “It started with a kiss”.

results.title: Song of the south
results.creator_credit: V.R. Sarma, M. Bhavnani and Films Division, Government of India
results.brief_description: Presents the Travancore-Cochin area of India, with a study of its arts, architecture and industries. Tea, rubber and cashew nuts are the main exports from Travancore-Cochin, and the growing of coconuts has developed the coir industry. The natural wealth of the area has in recent years facilitated the development of secondary industries such as aluminium, cement, rayon, ceramics, and chemical manufacture.

results.title: Song of the snows
results.creator_credit: N.S. Thapa, K Khandpur and Films Division, Government of India
results.brief_description: Out of the Himalayas rise the myths and legends, literature and culture of India. Shows the physical formation of snow, icicles, glaciers and rivers. This great mountain range is a challenge to mountaineers, a haven to pilgrims, and a source of immense beauty to all who come within its shadow.
results.creator_credit_for_label: N.S. Thapa, K Khandpur and Films Division, Government of India

results.title: Song of the prairie
results.brief_description: An animated puppet satire on the American western genre. Amusing stereotypes of typical characters from cowboy films which range from the whisky-swilling stagecoach driver and evil villain to the innocent heroine and singing hero. Music by Jan Rychlik.
results.description: An animated puppet satire on the American western genre. Amusing stereotypes of typical characters from cowboy films which range from the whisky-swilling stagecoach driver and evil villain to the innocent heroine and singing hero. Music by Jan Rychlik.

results.title: Song of the Clyde
results.brief_description: A study of the Clyde River, from its source at Elvanfoot to its mouth a Glasgow. This ships built on Clydesdale are famous throughout the world. The film shows the docks, shipyards, and wharves which line the Clyde as it enters the sea. Written by Harold Purcell. Music composed by George Posford, arranged and conducted by Peter Yorke.

results.title: Song festival
results.creator_credit: Edward Cline, Castle Films and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Selection of songs from the film “What’s cookin’” (Universal) including ‘I’ll pray for you’ sung by the Andrews Sisters with Woody Herman and his Orchestra, ‘Il bacio’ featuring Gloria Jean and ‘Amen’ with Jane Frayee.
